Saskatchewan 57 Campus Drive Saskatoon Saskatchewan S7N5A9 Canada Glycerol is a by-product in biodiesel production. It is possible to convert glycerol to glycerol carbonate by carbonylation with CO2. In this work, novel mixed metal oxides of Mg-Ca, Mg-Al, and Ca-Al were prepared by co-precipitation method, and used as catalysts for this reaction for the first time. Catalysts were characterized through XRD, BET surface area analyzer, XPS, ICP-OES, SEM, and CO2-TPD analyses. Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalyst showed the highest glycerol conversion of 18.2±0.7%, and glycerol carbonate yield of 12% at initial conditions. Reaction parameters including pressure, temperature, and catalyst loading were optimized, when Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalyst was used, to achieve the highest glycerol carbonate yield. The optimal reaction parameters were pressure of 7 MPa, temperature of 180 ⁰C, and catalyst loading of 8.5%. Glycerol conversion was 25.7% and the glycerol carbonate yield was 16% at optimized condition. Morphology and chemical structure of Mg-Ca catalyst were also investigated. Graphical Abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide Glycerol carbonate Mixed metal oxide Magnesium Calcium Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Glycerol is a by-product of biodiesel production process. Increasing the global demand for green fuels such as biodiesel in recent years has led to accumulation of high volume of glycerol. Biodiesel fuel is an alternative for fossil fuels as it is produced from renewable feedstocks such as vegetable oil and/or animal fat and employing it leads to emission of less carbon dioxide [1,2]. Upgrading and utilizing of waste glycerol into value-added products can increase the market price of glycerol and reduce its surplus. Conversion of excess glycerol to a value-added product such as glycerol carbonate is favored. Glycerol carbonate is applied as an initial chemical for polymerization, lubricants, personal care products, and solvents, and its price is estimated to be thirty four times higher than that of glycerol [3,4]. On the other hand, numerous studies have been conducted on consumption of carbon dioxide (CO2) [5], separation of CO2 [6], or reduction of its emission [7] since it acts as a greenhouse gas leading to global warming. In addition, conversion of glycerol to glycerol carbonate has been carried out through catalytic reaction with different reactants with glycerol such as dimethyl carbonate [8,9], urea [10,11], and carbon dioxide [12]. Among various reactants, CO2 reactant is low cost, and its application is beneficial to consume this greenhouse gas. Catalytic reaction of carbon dioxide and glycerol has been investigated in numerous studies. 7 wt% glycerol carbonate yield was achieved by using 6 mol% n-Bu2Sn(OMe)2 catalyst in the reaction under the condition of 5 MPa pressure, 180 ⁰C temperature, and 15 h reaction time [13]. Ozorio and Mota [12] tried five metal oxides including La2O3, CeO2, Fe2O3, SnO2, and ZnO in carbonylation of glycerol with CO2 at reaction conditions of 180 ⁰C, 150 bar, and 12 h. ZnO showed the highest catalyst activity with glycerol carbonate yield of 8.1%. La2O2CO3-ZnO was also used as a catalyst in the reaction by Li et al. [14] and the glycerol conversion of mere 6.9% was obtained under conditions of 150 ⁰C, 5.5 MPa, 20% catalyst loading, and 6 h. In our previous study, MgO, CaO, and Al2O3 metal oxide catalysts were used in the reaction since metal oxides are known as absorbents and activators of CO2 [15,16]. MgO showed the best catalytic activity in the reaction of glycerol with CO2 among the prepared catalysts with 12.8% glycerol carbonate yield, and 24.5% glycerol conversion at 8 MPa pressure, 150 ⁰C, and 5.5 wt% catalyst loading. To improve the activity of metal oxide catalysts, mixed metal oxides (MMOs) were considered. MMO catalysts have attracted attentions due to their acid-base properties and favorable surface area [17]. However, mixed metal oxides have been rarely used in the reaction of glycerol and CO2 to produce glycerol carbonate. In this work, novel catalysts of Aluminum-Magnesium, Calcium -Magnesium, and Aluminum-Calcium mixed metal oxide catalyst were synthesized and employed in the reaction for the first time. In addition, to the best of authors knowledge, this is the first time that an Aspen HYSYS simulation is applied to determine the optimum amount of the solvent for this reaction. Furthermore, a comprehensive study of the interactions in magnesium-calcium mixed metal oxide through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed in this paper for the first time. This study was performed in two steps. At the first step, mixed metal oxides of Mg-Al, Ca-Al, and Mg-Ca were prepared with equal molar amount of the metals. Physiochemical properties of the catalysts were determined through different characterization techniques including XRD, TPD, surface area analysis, and ICP. Performance of the prepared catalysts in the reaction of glycerol and CO2 was investigated. Analyses of GC and GC–MS were done on the obtained products of the reaction. Since the Mg-Ca mixed metal oxide showed the best catalyst activity in the reaction, two more catalysts with different ratios of Mg/Ca (Mg0.25Ca0.75O, and Mg0.75Ca0.25O) were prepared and characterized in the second step of the study. Characterization techniques including XRD, TPD, XPS, surface area analysis, SEM, and ICP were done at this step to understand the physio-chemical properties of these catalysts related to their catalytic activities. Furthermore, effects of reaction parameters were studied for the best catalyst. The parameters of the reaction were optimized to obtain the highest glycerol carbonate yield. At the optimum reaction conditions, the catalyst reusability was studied. All the reactions were conducted in presence of 2-cyanopyridine, as a dehydrator, to remove the side-product, water, and disturb the thermodynamics limitation of the reaction. Dimethyl formamide was also used as a solvent of both glycerol and carbon dioxide. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Glycerol (99.5%), 2-propanol (99.9%), N,N-Dimethylformamide (99.8%), sodium hydroxide (99%), calcium nitrate tetrahydrate (99%), and magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (99%) were obtained from Fisher Scientific (Ontario, Canada). 2-cyanopyridine (99%) was purchased from TCI America (OR, USA). Carbon dioxide gas (99.9%) was supplied by Linde Canada Inc. Sodium carbonate (99.5%) was obtained from VWR international LLC (USA), and aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (98%) was provided from Sigma-Aldrich Canada Ltd. (Ontario, Canada). Deionized water was used during all the aqueous experiments. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The MMOs of magnesium - calcium (Mg-Ca), calcium - aluminum (Ca-Al), and magnesium - aluminum (Mg-Al) were prepared by co-precipitation method. 0.2 M aqueous solution of pairwise metal precursors of Ca(NO3)2.4 H2O, Mg(NO3)2.6 H2O, or Al(NO3)3.9 H2O was prepared. A basic solution of Na2CO3 and NaOH was added dropwise to the above solution so that the pH was constant at 10±0.1. The obtained solution was kept under vigorous stirring for 10 h at ambient temperature. Then, the solution was vacuum-filtered and rinsed at least three times with deionized water. The resultant solid was dried in an oven for 12 h. The dry powder was then calcined in a muffle furnace in the presence of air with a heating rate of 2 ⁰C/min up to 800 ⁰C and kept at the constant temperature for 5 h. For further investigation, two more MMOs of Mg-Ca oxide were prepared with Mg molar contents of 25% and 75% using similar method (named Mg0.25Ca0.75O and Mg0.75Ca0.25O, respectively). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The chemical composition and crystallographic structure of the samples, as well as their physical properties were investigated by powder X-Ray diffraction patterns (XRD) using a Rigaku Ultima IV X-Ray Diffractometer, equipped with a Cu source (Kα1: 1.54060 Å and Kα2: 1.54443 Å), a scintillation counter detector, and crossbeam optics (CBO). The operation conditions of the diffractometer were 44 mA and 40 kV. For all the samples, 2θ was scanned from 10° to 90°, with 0.02° of a step size and an exposure time of 0.6 second per step (2 °/min scan rate). The BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of the catalysts were measured with a Micromeritics 3FLEX analyzer (3FLEX 3500) using liquid nitrogen at 77 K. Before the nitrogen adsorption-desorption started, a degassing condition of 4 h at 300 ⁰C was applied to the samples. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to measure the specific surface area at relative pressure range of 0.05–0.2 and to evaluate the pore sizes [18]. Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) were performed to identify the constituent metal loading in the samples by an iCAP 7000 series ICP-OES spectrometer (Thermo Fisher scientific). Before the analysis, 0.5 g of the sample was fully digested in 5 ml aqua regia solution (HCl: HNO3, 4:1 v/v), and heated on a hot plate at 60 ⁰C at least for 3 h. Then, volume of the obtained solution was increased up to 100 ml with diluted nitric acid. Before analysis, all the samples were filtered to make fully transparent solutions. Carbon dioxide temperature-programmed desorption (TPD-CO2) was measured with a Micromeritics AutoChem 2950 HP chemisorption Analyzer. Before measuring the desorption peaks, sample was heated up to 300 ⁰C under helium environment with the heating rate of 10 °C/min. The sample remained in the same condition for 30 minutes to be degassed. Then, it was cooled down to 100 ⁰C and exposed to the mixture of 5.2% CO2 in He for 30 minutes for adsorption of CO2 gas. Enough time was given to reach a stable baseline. Lastly, the sample went through the condition of 760 mmHg pressure, and heating from room temperature to 750 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min to desorb the CO2. Desorption recordings were done one per second. Surface morphology of the catalysts was investigated through scanning electron microscopy (SEM) operating a scanning electron microscope of Field-Emission Hitachi SU8010 (Hitachi High-Technologies, Canada). All samples were coated with Cr. To adjust the quality of SEM images, the scanning was done at a constant working distance of 3.8 mm, and under a vacuum mode at accelerating voltage of 3 kV with 6k and 40k magnifications. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) were collected on a Kratos AXIS Supra system (Manchester, UK) using a source of a 500 mm Rowland circle monochromated Al K-α (1486.6 eV) as the excitation source. It is equipped with a combination of a spherical mirror analyzer (SMA) and a hemi-spherical analyzer (HSA). Scans of three regions of each sample were conducted using 0.1 eV steps with a pass energy of 20 eV. The analysis conditions were an emission current of 15 mA and an accelerating voltage of 15 keV. The calibration of the XPS spectra was made using the carbon C1s reference peak. 2.4 Reaction procedure and experimental set-up 19 ml 2-cyanopyridine and 48 ml dimethylformamide were added to 12 ml glycerol in a batch reactor (stainless steel Parr reactor). Proper amount of catalyst was used in the reaction and the reactor was isolated and purged with CO2 gas at least 3 minutes. The pressure and temperature were adjusted on desired values. All the experiments were done under a rotational stirring speed of 500 rpm, and 24 h reaction time. The effects of reaction parameters on glycerol conversion and yield of glycerol carbonate were also determined by varying the three parameters of pressure, temperature, and catalyst loading. 2.5 Design of experiments and optimization of reaction parameters Reaction parameters including pressure, temperature, and catalyst loading were optimized to attain the maximum glycerol carbonate yield. The yield was modeled by response surface methodology. For that purpose, the yield was considered as response and pressure, temperature, and catalyst loading were considered as factors. Experiments were designed through central composite design (CCD). Table 1 shows level of the factors in experiments with different conditions of the reaction parameters. Coded values for axial points, factorial points, and central point were ±1.68, ±1, and 0, respectively. The experiments include 8 factorial points, 6 axial points, and 3 replicates of the central point. Initially, a quadratic regression model was developed for glycerol carbonate yield in terms of pressure, temperature, and catalyst loading. Significance of the model and the model terms was investigated by F-test and analysis of variance (ANOVA). Insignificant terms were removed from the regression model. Finally, the optimum reaction parameters and the maximum glycerol carbonate yield were determined using the regression model. Design of experiment, achieving regression model, ANOVA analysis, and optimization of reaction parameters were carried out using Design Expert software. 2.6 Product analysis At the end of the experiment, the reactor was cooled down and depressurized. A sample was taken from the contents of the reactor, then, filtered and diluted by ten times isopropanol. A quantitative analysis on the obtained solution was done by a gas chromatography instrument (Agilent 7890 A). The machine was equipped with a flame ionizing detector and a 30 m length capillary column. Final temperature of the oven was set at 300 ⁰C, and He was used as the carrier gas. The instrument automatically injected 1 μL of the solution into the column. The result of GC and GC–MS analysis confirmed the formation of glycerol carbonate. Following equations show the calculations for glycerol conversion (X), glycerol carbonate yield (Y), and glycerol carbonate selectivity (S): (1) X % = n G , in − n G , out n G , in × 100 (2) Y % = n GC , out n G , in × 100 (3) S % = Y X × 100 where nG,in, nG,out, and nGC,out refer to initial mole of glycerol, final mole of glycerol, and final mole of glycerol carbonate, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of solvent amount using Aspen HYSYS Production of glycerol carbonate occurred in a two-phase reaction between glycerol and carbon dioxide. Reaction of glycerol and carbon dioxide occurs in the liquid phase. Dimethyl formamide (DMF) solvent was used to bring CO2 into the liquid phase since DMF is a good solvent for CO2 as well as dissolving glycerol. According to stoichiometry of the reaction, molar ratio of CO2 to glycerol is equal to 1. To minimize the amount of consumed DMF, it was proposed to maintain the 1:1 molar ratio of carbon dioxide to glycerol. Utilizing simulations reduces experiment count, and aids in predicting optimal conditions [19]. For this purpose, the process before beginning of the reaction was simulated using Aspen HYSYS, and it was possible to determine mole of CO2 dissolved in the liquid phase. A scheme of the simulated process is presented in Fig. 1. In the simulation, an inlet stream of CO2 flows into the reactor, which is filled with the liquid phase including glycerol, DMF, and 2-cynopridine reactants. The volume, which is occupied by the gas phase, is determined by subtraction of the total reactor volume and volume of the liquid phase. Having the gas volume, temperature, and pressure, it is possible to calculate mole of the gas using ideal gas law. Therefore, flow of the inlet CO2 gas was set to a value so that mole of gas above the liquid in reactor is equal to the calculated amount. After simulation, molar ratio of CO2 / glycerol was determined at different volume ratios of DMF / glycerol and the results were presented in Fig. 2. The process temperature and pressure were 150 ⁰C and 5 MPa, respectively. It was observed that molar ratio of the reactants in the liquid phase was equal to 1 at DMF / glycerol volume ratio of 4. 3.2 Catalyst characterization study 3.2.1 X-ray diffraction To identify crystalline structures and crystallite sizes of the prepared catalysts, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out for the prepared catalysts. XRD patterns of the MMOs of Mg-Ca, Mg-Al, and Ca-Al catalysts with equimolar contribution of the metals are presented in Fig. 3. For magnesium-aluminum mixed oxide, the reflection showed peaks at 2θ values of 37.1°, 45°, and 65.4° corresponding to the diffraction planes of (Miller indices of 440), (400), and (311), respectively, which represents the formation of cubic MgAl2O4 spinel crystal phase (ICDD No.86–2258) [20,21]. In the calcium-aluminum oxide catalyst, besides CaO phase, two new phases were recognized as Ca12Al14O33 due to the presence of peaks at 2θ values of 18.2°, 27.9°, 33.5°, 35.2°, and 41.3° (ICDD 00–009–0413), and CaAl2O4 due to the formed peaks at 2θ values of 29.9°, 35.2°, 37.4°, 44.2°, and 46.7° (ICDD 01–070–0134) [22]. Considering the XRD patterns of both above-mentioned MMOs, new crystalline phases of mixed oxides were identified. The XRD pattern of magnesium-calcium oxide sample shown in Fig. 3 clearly indicated the existence of two crystalline phases of MgO and CaO, correspond to pure oxides and no new chemical mixture was observed of the MMO phase. This is probably because of the different ionic radii of these two metal ions [23]. 3.2.2 Surface area Table 2 shows the BET surface areas of the prepared Mg-Al, Ca-Al, and Mg-Ca Oxides (1:1) catalysts, as well as their average pore size and pore volume values. The data were derived from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller algorithm. The BET surface area of the samples was in the range of 4.5–11.2 m2/g. Among the catalysts, the highest BET surface area and highest average pore diameter belonged to the Mg-Ca oxide with 11.2 m2/g and 41.6 nm, respectively. 3.2.3 Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy The efficiency of co-precipitation method in the synthesis of mixed metal oxides was evaluated by ICP-OES elemental analyzer. Table 2 shows the molar ratios of metal species in each of the MMOs synthesized by co-precipitation, under the same aging time and temperature, explained in Section 2.2. The actual molar fractions of metal1/metal 2 for Mg-Al oxide (1:1), Ca-Al oxide (1:1), and Mg-Ca oxide (1:1), were 0.93, 0.96, and 0.836 respectively, which are in good agreement with the theoretical values, indicating a successful synthesis of the mixed metal oxides. The discordance between the theoretical and the actual values might be due to non-uniform distribution of the species in the samples [24]. 3.2.4 CO2- temperature-programmed desorption CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) of Mg-Al, Ca-Al, and Mg-Ca MMOs (metal 1 to metal 2 molar ratio of 1:1) was performed to quantify the amount of basicity of the catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 4. Table 3 demonstrates the basic site distribution of the catalysts over the temperature range of room temperature to 750 ⁰C. This range was divided into three regions including weak basic sites with the range of room temperature to 250 ⁰C, 250–500 ⁰C as sites with moderate basic strength, and above 500 ⁰C as high basic strength sites. CO2-TPD profile of Mg-Al mixed oxide sample gave two weak peaks at lower temperature range centred at 65 ⁰C and 145 ⁰C, indicating the sites with weak interactions with adsorbed CO2. Much higher amount of desorbed CO2 was interpreted from a strong desorption peak for the catalyst at temperatures between 515 ⁰C to 720 ⁰C with a peak maximum at 630 ⁰C, which showed the most basic sites of this catalyst due to strong interaction with adsorbed CO2. From Table 3, the total amount of basicity of Mg-Al mixed oxide is 1144 µmol of desorbed CO2 per gram of catalyst, which is higher than the total basicity of both Al2O3 (331 µmol of CO2/g) and MgO (899 µmol of CO2/g) catalysts obtained from the authors’ previous work [25]. It can be caused by the formation of the new phase of MgAl2O4, which has shown higher number of basic sites. A significant intense CO2 desorption peak showed up for Ca-Al mixed oxide between the temperatures of 488–691 ⁰C, centred at 607 ⁰C, showing the interaction of CO2 with sites of high basic strength. While both CaO and Al2O3 pure samples have peaks at low and medium basic strength ranges [25], no CO2 desorption peak before 488 ⁰C was observed for Ca-Al mixed oxide in its CO2-TPD profile. This could be due to the formation of new phases of CaAl2O4 and Ca12Al14O33 which was observed at its XRD results. Ca-Al mixed oxide also showed higher total basicity (1444 µmol of CO2/g) in comparison with each pure oxide of CaO (869 µmol of CO2/g) and Al2O3 (331 µmol of CO2/g). CO2-TPD profile of Mg-Ca mixed oxide showed a broad peak over temperature range of 31–356 ⁰C, indicating a large number of sites with low and medium basic strength in interaction with CO2. Where this peak ended, a sharp and intense peak appeared, maximum at 461 ⁰C and ended at 495 ⁰C. The peak indicates the amount of medium basic strength sites. From Table 3, Mg-Ca MMO catalyst has the total basicity amount of 713 µmol of CO2/g, which is higher than the basicity of MgO and CaO. The improved basicity of the mixed metal oxide could be caused by the synergistic effect between MgO and CaO molecules. 3.3 Catalytic activity study For the first catalyst screening, MMO samples of Mg-Al, Ca-Al, and Mg-Ca, with equal molar ratio of the two metals, were evaluated under similar conditions as follows: temperature of 150 ⁰C, pressure of 5 MPa, catalyst loading of 5.5 wt% of the glycerol inlet, and 24 hours of the reaction. Fig. 5 displays the catalysts performance in the glycerol conversion reaction. Screening the catalysts showed the glycerol conversion in the range of 10.9±1.3% to 17.9±1.0% for Ca-Al oxide and Mg-Ca oxide, respectively. Mg-Ca oxide sample also showed the highest glycerol carbonate yield among Mg-Al, Ca-Al, and Mg-Ca oxide catalysts, with 10%. Using Ca-Al and Mg-Al oxides showed lower glycerol conversion compared to Mg-Ca oxide sample. This may be due to the lower BET surface area of these samples, which had fewer active sites to convert glycerol. 3.4 Optimization of Mg-Ca oxide composition 3.4.1 Catalyst characterization study 3.4.1.1 X-ray Diffraction For further investigation of the effects of the selected catalyst in step one on the reaction performance, catalysts with two more ratios of Mg/Ca were prepared. The two additional catalysts with different ratios of Mg/Ca of 3:1 and 1:3 (named Mg0.75Ca0.25O and Mg0.25Ca0.75O) were examined by X-ray diffraction and their patterns are shown in Fig. 6. It is observed that a homogeneous physical mixture of MgO and CaO exists in all the Mg-Ca mixed oxides, without any formation of mixed phases. Comparing the FWHM (full width at half maximum) of CaO peaks also shows that by increasing the amount of Ca loading, the degree of the crystallinity of CaO increased, leading to higher CaO particle size, based on Debye-Scherrer equation. 3.4.1.2 Surface area and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy Table 4 shows the BET surface areas of Mg0.25Ca0.75O, and Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalysts, as well as their average pore sizes and pore volumes. The results showed that at a constant calcination temperature, by increasing the ratio of Mg/Ca in Mg-Ca catalyst, the porosity, pore size, and pore volume increased, since the highest BET surface area of 15.2 m2/g belonged to Mg0.75Ca0.25O. This catalyst also showed the highest average pore diameter of 45.2 nm, and the highest pore volume of 0.172 cm3/g among all the prepared catalysts. The surface area results are also in good agreement with XRD results as the catalyst with the lower surface area showed a narrower peak and, hence, a larger crystal size, based on Debye-Scherrer equation. The actual molar fractions of metal1/metal 2 for these two catalysts were 0.28, and 2.54, from Table 4, which are in good agreement with the theoretical values (0.333, and 3, respectively), indicating a successful synthesis of the mixed Mg-Ca oxide catalysts. 3.4.1.3 CO2- temperature-programmed desorption CO2-TPD profiles of Mg-Ca MMOs with different molar ratios of Mg/Ca is depicted in Fig. 7. All the profiles showed a broad peak from ambient temperature to around 350 ⁰C, followed by a more intense and sharper peak. A precise comparison shows that the first broad peak was more intense by increasing the amount of Mg in the Mg-Ca catalyst. It is also observed that the second CO2 desorption peak location moved toward higher temperatures and intensified with increasing the percentage of Mg in the mixture of Mg-Ca oxide. Table 5 shows the basic site distributions for the Mg-Ca catalysts. There are no strong basic sites reported for Mg0.25Ca0.75O and Mg0.5Ca0.5O, while Mg0.75Ca0.25O showed 1904.5 µmol of desorbed CO2/g at temperatures higher than 500 ⁰C. Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalyst also showed the highest total basicity of 2625 µmol of CO2/g among all prepared catalysts. Moreover, the data proves that by increasing the ratio of Mg/Ca in the catalyst from 0.33 to 3, the basicity of the catalyst and the number of strong basic sites increased. Mg and Ca ions have different electronic configurations, which can influence the electronic properties of the catalyst surface. Changes in the Mg/Ca ratio may induce electronic effects that affect the binding energy of CO2 molecules on the catalyst surface, thereby altering the desorption behavior observed in the CO2-TPD test. The electronic structure of the adsorbed CO2 species plays a role in their desorption behavior. Changes in the electronic properties of the catalyst surface induced by variations in the Mg/Ca ratio may influence the electronic structure of adsorbed CO2 species, affecting their desorption kinetics and temperature. 3.4.1.4 Scanning electron microscopy Contribution of CaO and MgO metal oxides to morphology of Mg-Ca MMO catalysts was investigated through comparison of SEM images of CaO, MgO, and Mg-Ca oxide catalysts with different ratios of Mg and Ca as presented in Fig. 8. The SEM images show two different arrangements of MgO and CaO catalysts since MgO was rod-shaped (Fig. 8. d), while CaO was relatively spherical (Fig. 8. a). Fig. 8. b shows the MMO with lower amount of Mg (Mg0.25Ca0.75O) and it is observed that CaO surface was decorated by small MgO pieces. In the MMO with higher amount of Mg (Mg0.75Ca0.25O) (Fig. 8. c), it is observed that the surface of CaO catalyst was homogeneously covered by higher amount of MgO particles. Contrary to literature that concluded CaO masks MgO particles and prohibits MgO to adsorb more CO2 on its surface [26], the SEM results show that CaO does not cover MgO particles but MgO totally losses its rod-like shape in the structure of Mg-Ca oxide and spreads on the surface of CaO, which is clearly observable from Fig. 8. b and c. MgO segments that occupied the surface of CaO had smaller sizes than pure MgO rod-like chunks. 3.4.1.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Considering the better performance of Mg-Ca mixed metal oxide catalyst, its surface chemistry was further investigated through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). To understand the interactions of elements, XPS spectra of Mg-Ca MMO was compared with the spectra of MgO and CaO single oxide catalysts. Table 6 provides surface composition of the three catalysts. Similar to bulk composition results obtained from ICP-OES characterization and presented in Tables 2 and 4, Mg content is less than Ca content on the surface obtained from XPS data. In this case, magnesium to calcium ratio is 0.048. However, magnesium content on the surface is much less than that in the bulk. Therefore, the surface elemental composition is not necessarily representative of the entire bulk. Differences between the compositions of surface and bulk have been reported in numerous studies [27]. Mg 2p spectra of MgO and Mg-Ca mixed metal oxide catalysts are presented in Fig. 9. It is observed that the spectra for both catalysts showed three components of Mg(OH)2, MgO, and MgCO3 and the peak positions are almost the same for the metal oxide and MMO catalysts. Fig. 10 presents the spectra for Ca 2p for CaO and Mg-Ca mixed metal oxide catalysts. Ca 2p spectra showed two peaks with a valley, which agrees with the observation in previous studies [28,29]. The peak with the lower binding energy is attributed to 2p3/2 and the one with higher energy is for 2p1/2. Each peak of Ca 2p can be deconvoluted to three peaks for CaO, Ca(OH)2 and CaCO3 components [30,31]. The peaks of Ca(OH)2 and CaCO3 components of 2p3/2, and Ca(OH)2 of 2p1/2 shifted between 0.5 and 0.7 eV to higher binding energies in Mg-Ca MMO compared with the peak positions in CaO catalyst. While the peak for CaCO3 component of 2p1/2 shifted from 350.5 eV in CaO to the higher binding energy of 352.9 eV in the MMO catalyst, CaO peak positions were unchanged when comparing the CaO and the Ca-Mg mixed metal oxide catalysts. The lower percentage of peak area corresponding to CaO and the greater area of other components in the MMO sample compared to the CaO sample, may be attributed to moisture absorption and the adsorption of CO2 from the environment. Typically, the peak area for Ca 2p ½ is half that of the Ca 2p3/2 peak. When Ca is exposed to Mg, there is an overlap of the Mg KLL peak with the Ca 2p ½ peak, potentially causing confusion in the deconvolution of Ca 2p ½ peaks. The Mg x-ray induces a Mg KLL Auger peak. The position of the Mg KLL peak can be identified from the survey scan of MgO, which is located at 350.0 eV. This peak is depicted in the deconvoluted peaks in Fig. 10.b. By isolating this peak, the other Ca 2p peaks can be deconvoluted effectively as shown in Fig. 10.b. The XPS analysis showed that the single and mixed metal oxide catalysts contain carbonate and hydroxide groups on their surfaces. Similar results were observed in previous studies. The carbonate content is due to reaction of the metal oxides with carbon dioxide of the air in the outermost surface layer and the hydroxide content is due to sorption of H2O [30-32]. Comparison of both Mg 2p and O 1 s spectra of MgO and Mg-Ca MMO catalysts shows that less hydroxide exists in the mixed oxide catalyst compared to the single oxide one as the area of metal hydroxide in Mg 2p spectra decreased from 25.7% for MgO catalyst to 8% for Mg-Ca MMO catalyst. As well, the area of metal hydroxide in O1s spectra decreased from 58.9% for MgO catalyst to 38.9% for Mg-Ca mixed metal oxide catalyst. Investigation of Mg 2p spectra show that amount of MgCO3 component did not significantly change in MgO catalyst compared to Mg-Ca MMO catalyst. Investigation of XPS spectra of different elements of the catalysts shows that the peak positions do not change for most of the elements. Mg-Ca MMO catalyst has been used for production of biodiesel in previous research studies and a physical mixture of two single oxides with no interaction of the two phases was concluded using XRD patterns [23,24,26] as it was also concluded by comparison of XRD patterns of this work. However, a few shifts are observed in XPS spectra in this work as discussed, suggesting that some chemical interactions might exist between the phases as well as the physical interactions in the mixture. 3.4.2 Catalytic activity study The two catalysts of Mg0.25Ca0.75O and Mg0.75Ca0.25O were examined at similar reaction conditions of Section 3.3 and the results are shown in Fig. 11. The outcome showed that increasing the Mg content in the Mg-Ca MMO catalyst resulted in higher catalyst activity in the reaction. Increasing the Mg/Ca ratio from 1:3–1:1 increased the glycerol conversion from 14.8% to 17.9%. This increase continued to glycerol conversion of 18.2±0.7% using the catalyst with the Mg/Ca ratio of 3:1. The glycerol conversion growth is probably due to the increase in the BET surface area of the catalysts. The highest ratio of Mg/Ca (Mg0.75Ca0.25O) also showed the highest glycerol carbonate yield in the reaction with 12%. This catalyst also showed the highest BET surface area (15.2 m2/g) among the others. It is noticeable that the highest selectivity belonged to the Mg0.75Ca0.25O, which had the highest basicity amount. This shows that higher basicity favors the production of glycerol carbonate. To have a better view on the performance of all prepared catalysts, followings are comparisons of their activity, BET surface area, and basicity amount: Activity: Mg0.75Ca0.25O > Mg-Ca Oxide > Mg-Al Oxide > Ca-Al Oxide > Mg0.25Ca0.75O Surface area: Mg0.75Ca0.25O > Mg-Ca Oxide > Mg-Al Oxide > Mg0.25Ca0.75O > Ca-Al Oxide Basicity: Mg0.75Ca0.25O > Ca-Al Oxide > Mg-Al Oxide > Mg-Ca Oxide > Mg0.25Ca0.75O This comparison shows that BET surface area is not the only factor which affects catalyst activity. It proved that there is another factor which compete with surface area to affect the catalyst activity. Besides surface area, the number of basic sites also has effect on catalyst activity. This conclusion is in agreement with other studies in the literature [33,34]. It is noteworthy that based on GC-MS results, the side products of glycerol carbonate were 2-hydroxybenzeneacetic acid, styrene, and 2-pyridinecarboxylic acid. Turnover Number (TON) is a crucial parameter to evaluate the efficiency of a catalyst in a catalytic reaction. Higher TON indicates that the catalyst is more efficient in catalyzing the reaction. Table 7 displays the TON values of the synthesized catalysts. The TON data, determined based on basic active sites, were calculated using the following equation. [34]: (4) TON = Produced glycerol carbonate ( μ mol glycerol carbonate / g catalyst ) Basic site amount ( μ mol CO 2 / g catalyst ) The Mg0.25Ca0.75O catalyst exhibited the highest TON value at 181.6 μmol glycerol carbonate per μmol CO2, whereas the Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalyst displayed the lowest turnover number at 32.2 μmol glycerol carbonate per μmol CO2. Notably, all these values surpass the reported TONs of their individual oxides, including CaO, MgO, and Al2O3 [35]. While low reactivity of carbon dioxide is an important reason for low glycerol conversion in general, the lower TON of Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalyst might be due to the fact that this catalyst, while highly selective, is not as efficient in converting reactants into the desired product per mole of catalyst. This can occur because the catalyst's active sites are highly selective but perhaps less active in promoting the main reaction pathway. The catalyst may excel in selectivity but not in the overall efficiency of promoting each step of the reaction pathway, leading to a lower TON. This result could also signal an opportunity for further optimization of the reaction conditions while maintaining its selectivity. Overall, although the Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalyst showed less TON than other catalysts, but its high yield is a broader measure of how well the reaction converted the reactants into products, accounting for all factors in the reaction system. 3.4.3 Optimization of reaction parameters Pressure, temperature, and catalyst loading are three reaction parameters which can affect performance of glycerol and carbon dioxide reaction [36,37]. Since the mixed metal oxide of Mg0.75Ca0.25O showed the best performance in the reaction, the optimization experiments were performed in the presence of that catalyst. Regression models of glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield were obtained in terms of the reaction parameters to investigate effects of reaction parameters on the glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield and to determine optimum reaction parameters giving maximum glycerol carbonate yield. Response surface methodology (RSM) was used with 17 experiments designed based on central composite design. In using RSM, catalyst loading (X1), pressure (X2), and temperature (X3) were the factors and glycerol conversion (Y1), and glycerol carbonate yield (Y2) were the responses. Table 8 presents the list of experiments at different reaction conditions and values of responses. Regression models of Y1 and Y2 in terms of X1, X2, and X3 were obtained using a quadratic model. F-test and ANOVA analysis were used to evaluate significance of the regression model and the model terms. ANOVA analysis for glycerol conversion regression model and glycerol carbonate yield regression model are presented in Table 9 and Table 10, respectively. It is observed that the model was significant for the regression models of glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield. For the glycerol conversion regression model, X1 X2, X1 X3, X2 X3, and X3 2 terms were not significant. For the glycerol carbonate yield regression model, X1 X2, X1 X3, and X2 X3 terms were not significant. The regression models after elimination of the insignificant terms are presented in equations below as: (4) Y1=17.65+4.16 X1+1.92 X2+4.2 X3-2.28 X1 2-0.95 X2 2 (5) Y2=11.96+2.59 X1+2.62 X2+2.32 X3-2.2 X1 2-1.26 X2 2-2.14 X3 2 R2 of glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield regression models were 95.9% and 94.7%, respectively. According to the regression models, glycerol conversion increases with X1, X2, and X3 and decreases with X1 2 and X2 2 and glycerol carbonate yield increases with X1, X2, and X3 and decreases with X1 2, X2 2, and X3 2. Figs. 12 and 13 show surface plots of the regression models. Reaction parameters were optimized to obtain maximum glycerol carbonate yield. The maximum obtained glycerol carbonate yield was 16% and glycerol conversion was 25.7% at the pressure of 7 MPa, temperature of 180 ⁰C, and catalyst loading of 8.5%. The results indicated that increasing pressure from 1.6 MPa to 8.4 MPa resulted in a continues increase in glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield. This is due to the presence of more CO2 in the liquid phase as the carbonate source in the reaction as a result of the higher CO2 pressure [16,36]. Getting towards the end of the range showed less pressure effect on glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield. Raising temperature from 100 ⁰C to 200 ⁰C caused continuous increase in glycerol conversion, proved that the reaction is endothermic [36,38]. Increasing temperature favors the glycerol carbonate production up to a maximum, and then showed a slight decrease in glycerol carbonate yield. The drop in glycerol carbonate yield could be contributed to the production of side products and decomposition of glycerol carbonate at higher temperatures [34,38–40]. Effect of catalyst amount on the reaction was investigated between 0.5 wt% to 10.5 wt% of glycerol amount. Glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield increased by increasing the amount of catalyst to a maximum followed by a downward trend by increasing more in loading of catalyst. Increasing catalyst loading provided more active sites for the reaction, favored glycerol conversion and glycerol carbonate yield. Glycerol conversion decrease could be attributed to the agglomeration of the catalyst powder and possible mass transfer resistance into the active sites of the catalyst [41]. On the other hand, higher amount of catalyst loading favors the hydrolysis of 2-picolinamide, which causes more formation of side products and consequently lower glycerol carbonate yield [39]. 3.4.4 Catalyst reusability The catalyst with the highest activity, Mg0.75Ca0.25O, was selected for the reusability study to demonstrate its stability. The reactions were done at the optimum reaction conditions. After the reaction, the used catalyst was separated by vacuum filtration and washed with methanol at least three times and dried at 105 ℃. XRD analysis revealed that the used catalyst lost its CaO species and new peaks including CaCO3 and CaH2O2 showed up. Upon heating the used catalyst at 800 ℃ for 5 h, the catalyst was recovered and showed the same XRD pattern as the fresh catalyst in XRD data. A comparison of the XRD patterns is depicted in Fig. 14. The activity results of each catalyst after using and recovery heating are illustrated in Fig. 15. The results indicate that the activity of the catalyst remained nearly constant, with only 2.6% decrease in glycerol carbonate yield after three cycles. This result shows the effectiveness of heating in restoring the used catalyst, and the stability of the catalyst up to three cycles. Table 11 presents a comparison of results obtained from glycerol and carbon dioxide reactions, in conjunction with literature values. The data highlights the performance and outcomes of our study in relation to previous research. 4 Conclusions Mixed metal oxide catalysts of Mg-Ca, Mg-Al, and Al-Ca were used in the reaction of glycerol and CO2 to produce glycerol carbonate. Mixed oxide of Ca-Al was formed as Ca12Al14O33 and CaAl2O4, and Mg-Al mixed oxide was formed as MgAl2O4. Mg-Ca mixed oxide did not show strong chemical bonds although comparison of XPS spectra of MgO, CaO, and Mg-Ca mixed metal oxide catalysts revealed possibility of chemical interactions between magnesium oxide and calcium oxide phases. MgO catalyst was rod-shape and CaO catalyst was semi-spherical. In the mixed metal oxide of magnesium and calcium, MgO particles were not rod-shape anymore and had smaller sizes than those of pure MgO. The small size MgO components were dispersed on the CaO component in the mixed metal oxide. The mixed metal oxides of Ca-Al and Mg-Al had higher basicity in compared with their single oxides. This might be due to the formation of their new mixed oxide phases. Among the mixed metal oxides with equimolar ratios of the metals, Mg-Ca mixed metal oxide showed the highest BET surface area, glycerol conversion, and glycerol carbonate yield. Investigation of Mg-Ca mixed metal oxide with different metal ratios demonstrated that by increasing the ratio of Mg/Ca in Mg-Ca catalyst from 0.33 to 3, the basicity of the catalyst and the number of strong basic sites increased. It has been also observed that the one with Mg/Ca molar ratio of 3 showed the highest basicity, BET surface area, glycerol conversion, and glycerol carbonate yield. The highest glycerol carbonate yield was attributed to Mg0.75Ca0.25O mixed metal oxide catalyst at temperature of 180 ⁰C, pressure of 7 MPa, and catalyst loading of 8.5% with glycerol conversion of 25.7% and glycerol carbonate yield of 16%. The optimum catalyst can be used up to tree cycles with a negligible drop in glycerol carbonate yield, with the help of heating treatment after each use. coredata.dc:description: Glycerol is a by-product in biodiesel production. It is possible to convert glycerol to glycerol carbonate by carbonylation with CO2. In this work, novel mixed metal oxides of Mg-Ca, Mg-Al, and Ca-Al were prepared by co-precipitation method, and used as catalysts for this reaction for the first time. Catalysts were characterized through XRD, BET surface area analyzer, XPS, ICP-OES, SEM, and CO2-TPD analyses. Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalyst showed the highest glycerol conversion of 18.2±0.7%, and glycerol carbonate yield of 12% at initial conditions. Reaction parameters including pressure, temperature, and catalyst loading were optimized, when Mg0.75Ca0.25O catalyst was used, to achieve the highest glycerol carbonate yield. The optimal reaction parameters were pressure of 7 MPa, temperature of 180 ⁰C, and catalyst loading of 8.5%. Glycerol conversion was 25.7% and the glycerol carbonate yield was 16% at optimized condition. Morphology and chemical structure of Mg-Ca catalyst were also investigated.
coredata.dc:title: Structural study of mixed metal oxide catalysts comprising Mg, Ca, and Al used for upgrading biodiesel byproduct glycerol to glycerol carbonate
